text:
Hi guys, I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to show you

how to make a delicious berries and cream
crepes.

I love this and I thought this would be a
really special breakfast, whether it be for

Mother's Day, or Easter or a random Tuesday,
if I'm coming over, but I'm just not saying,

but I would appreciate it, I'm not pushing
it, but if you went the extra mile to make

these for breakfast if I was your guest, I
might stay there a little bit longer, which

might not be what you want, but you get the
gist.

They're so good, very easy and simple and
I love them and I feel like they're just a

little bit more special than just say a stack
of pancakes which, hey, nothing wrong with

that but if you make these for a special weekend
brunch or something like that I think you'll

go down in history because people will love
it.

The ingredients for the crepes are very basic,
they're very simple standard ingredients,

flour, pinch of salt, little bit of sugar,
eggs, melted butter, whole milk, that's all
you need.
And a purple spatula.

I love making my crepe batter in a blender
because you do need this to be really really

smooth, so what I like to do, you've got your
blender, I'm going to add all of the liquid

first and then I'll give that a whiz just
to make sure it's all incorporated before

I add the flour, so I've got the eggs, the
milk, or as Mia would say 'muk'.

And the butter, and I'm just going to pop
this on and let it whisk until combined.

That's good, alright now we're going to add
in all of the dry ingredients, like I said,

I've got flour, a little pinch of sugar, and
a little bit of salt and I am in the near

future going to share with you how to make
some savory crepes.

Because those, I really do love sweet crepes,
I do, my crepe cake is one of my favorite

things in the entire world, but a savory crepe
like a ham and bechamel Swiss situation, ohh
so good!

I'm going to pop this on and I'm going to
let this go for a good minute or two, I need

it to be really smooth, make sure the lid
is on, I made that mistake once or twice.
And then you just let it go.
Okay, perfect.

I'm going to pour the batter back into the
bowl that I had my dry ingredients in just

because it's going to make it a lot easier
when I go to make the crepes.
Look at that.
Smooth, beautiful batter.

Okay, now very important, you want to make
the batter with some kind of immersion blender

situation because you need to get it that
smooth and I think a blender works the best,

but an immersion blender will do just fine,
I would suggest that you put the ingredients

on sort of like a large pitcher or a large
mason jar or something like that because it

really helps break up any lumps, equally as
important is letting the batter rest.

I'm going to let this rest for about twenty
minutes or so and I will show you when we
start making crepes.
I mean that's pretty much it right now.
Alright, first crepe.

The first I always feel like it's kind of
like your first pancake, it's always the most

wonky one until you kind of get into a groove,
what I've got here is a little bit of light

olive oil or any flavorless oil, I've got
a nine inch non-stick pan pre-heated over

about medium heat and the second you put your
batter in you have to swirl it around so that

the batter coats the bottom of the pan, these
cook really quickly and really easily and

you're not looking for them to be like a golden
brown color because it's not going to take

that long for them to cook in order to get
there, but they'll be a beautiful blonde color

and they're just perfect, I love this recipe
and I think you will too, you;ll know when

it's time to flip when you can actually see
that the top looks dry, it means that the
other side is done.

I would suggest you don't do this with your
hand, and if it loosely peels itself off then

you know the bottom is done, otherwise you
just kind of have to give it a push with the

spatula, the first few are always, like I
said, wonky, but that's when you get into
a groove.

And I'm going to continue to make a few more,
I'm not going to make all of them from the

batter because the batter actually saves well
in the fridge for days, so if you want to

make a batch of the batter, keep it in a mason
jar in the fridge for the week and make them

fresh every morning, then you can definitely
do that because it lasts so, so well.

I've got some done with a little color on
them, the more you make the better they come
out really.

I've got some done, I'm going to work on the
berry part now because it's got to cool for

a bit, I have some frozen mixed berries here
you can use fresh if you want to but I think

when it comes to this amount of mixed berries,
the best bang for your buck is to buy them
frozen.

I'm going to add sugar to that, lower the
heat a little bit and I'm going to add a little

bit of zest of a clementine, you could use
an orange or you could leave it out completely,

or use a little bit of zest of lemon if you
want to, and then I'm going to squeeze in
the juice of the clementine as well.

I like what it adds and what it brings to
the table.

It's so special too, like I said for a holiday
breakfast, love it, okay add that in.

And we're just going to cook these until the
berries basically thaw and the sugar melts,

it will come to a boil and I'll show you what
it looks like when it gets there because it

could take a few minutes but like I said the
best bang for your buck when it comes to using

a bunch of mixed berries, say in this case
I need two cups total, everything together,

buying them frozen if you're going to cook
them anyway, makes the most sense otherwise

you have to buy a carton of each one and you
will only need some of each one, you know
what I mean?
So, this just works out really well.

That looks amazing, you can also do this by
the way, using only blueberries which I really

like as well, but I like the mixture of all
three together because you get the visual
of the strawberries, and it's just good.

In here I've got a little bit of corn starch,
add a little bit of water to it, make a little

slurry, corn starch always wants cold liquid,
add a little bit more.

And then we're going to pour this into here
and let it cook for a couple of minutes until

it's no longer cloudy and it will thicken

to take this off the heat, and let it cool
slightly and then we'll get going on making

Last thing to work on is the creamy component

You can make the crepes a couple days before,
